title: What is the coolest feature of your phone? - Quora

response.answer_text: After years of using the same old phone, watching the 8gb of memory fill up to the point where I had to delete photos and clear the cache to update apps, watching the battery life get (only slightly) worse, and finally, watching Google cut it off from future updates, I recently got a new phone. I chose the Nexus 5x. The 6p may have better specs, but the 5x fits in my pocket. This phone has a lot of great features, and it is hard to pick just one. Here are a few of my favorites. Fingerprint scanner: On the back of the phone is a fingerprint scanner. Instead of pressing buttons, entering a code, or swiping a pattern, I can just pick up the phone. It quickly becomes a habit to pick it up with a finger on the scanner. As soon as I touch the scanner, the phone instantly unlocks. No buttons pressed, no passwords or pattern entered. This sounds like a minor thing, but you quickly realize how easy and convenient it is. Great camera: My old Nexus 4 had many good qualities, but the camera was not one of them. The 5X has a camera that will probably make me retire my stand alone point and shoot camera. Pictures come out great in all conditions and I can even record high frame rate slow motion video. I love photography, and with this phone, getting good quality images is much easier to do. Stock Android: I know a lot of people who say they hate Android. It is too confusing and they’ll switch back to an iPhone as soon as they can, despite it costing more than $700. I used to have no idea what they were talking about, until my dad asked me for help with his Samsung. Many manufacturers put skins over top of Android that are just awful. Do I want to use the Google email app, the AT&T one, or the Samsung one? Don’t you just love the color neon green and silly bloop and bleep noises whenever you touch the phone? Trying to find something in the settings? Good luck! Maybe some physical buttons (and therefore less screen real estate) are your thing!  It was not a good experience, and I see why he would want to use something simpler. I don’t have those problems. Android, as Google designed it, is actually pretty damn good. It is easy to find the information you need, and while there are some useless apps that come installed and can’t be removed, there are far fewer of them. The new Material Design standard makes things look very modern and nice, without even a hint of blue on neon green color clashing. Getting rid of all this junk also makes the phone run faster. There is one more benefit of not having a carrier or manufacturer skin over top of Android to be approved… Fast updates: My phone is running Android 6.0.1 with the January level of security patches. Next month, assuming there isn’t a more substantial update before then, I will get another security update. Google can do this because once the updated version of the software is ready, they can send it out to the phones. Samsung doesn’t have to take it and add all their junk to it. AT&T and Verizon don’t need to drag their feet for months testing it and adding their own stuff. iPhone users have a similar experience, with the updates coming directly from Apple, but it is much more rare in the Android world.  I could go on with other reasons that I chose this phone, but the above reasons are the most important features that affected my decision. At least some of these things can be found on other phones,  but this one represented the best combination for me.

My favorite feature on a smartphone is the IR blaster. Whoever thought of putting one on a phone was a genius. Just think of it. You always have your phone but the TV remote is always lost. I can't count the number of times that my phone has saved the day. Additionally, it is very convenient because I am a bit lazy and sometimes I do not feel to get up and get the remote and my phone was there for me to use. My first experience with this was when I got the LG G2. I really loved it. It really pained me when I upgraded to the S7 edge and found out that it didn't have the IR blaster. I know not many people use the IR port on their phones but come on Sammy. Please bring it back.

Hi, The coolest feature that I very recently found on my *Android* smartphone was that of location tracking.   So basically what it does is keep a track of where you have been, for how long and how often. And the best thing is that all this data is there for you to see and analyse at the end of the day. The only downside that I see is that it might take a hit on your battery life since you need to keep your GPS on at all times. This also means an active data pack for all your needs. How to Activate? Open the App Drawer and go to Settings.Scroll down and tap Location.Scroll down and tap Google Location Settings.Tap Location Reporting and Location History, and switch the slider to on for each one.You can view all the data on your laptop from this link : Sign in - Google Accounts  The Result : I have kept location tracking on for the last 1 year, and this is a sample pic that you might get :   This is over an year, but you can change the month and day to find out what you were doing on a specific day. Note : I am not sure how to get a similar feature on iOS. Never used one! Hope it helps!!

I use an LG L90 phone.It's got an IR blaster (universal remote for TV and several other devices).  During one IPL match between CSK vs some other team, which was heading towards a nail-biting finish, I managed to switch off the TV(without anyones knowledge) of the cafeteria where some hundreds of people were watching. In our company, we used have big LED TVs(65" Panasonic) instead of projectors in our conference rooms.  I used to switch off the TV in the middle of some serious presentation (of course, in such a manner that no one knows how it got switched off)

I use a Google Nexus 6 (previous gen) made by Motorola. In terms of what I love about it the most, i.e., one thing, it would be the beautiful large 6 inch screen. A bit large for most users, it is perfect for web sites and reading e-mail when I am not at my desk. The large size makes it only a bit more clunky as a voice phone … but using a Bluetooth headset alleviates any issues with holding it that close to my ear. The large screen provides ample space (at very high resolution) to use the “desktop”, non-mobile pages for sites. With pinch zoom in and out, the desktop versions of web pages are perfectly usable on this phone! Also, I am not a movie buff, but received one free movie with the original purchase, as I recall. So, I watched “Gravity” on a plane trip - that was an awesome experience. The screen was perfectly sized for this close usage.

I own a OnePlus 3. Must say it is fantabulous phone for the price! Features i love: Customizations like swapping navigation buttons (I can even choose to have on-screen buttons and completely disable the two capacitive keys on either side of fingerprint scanner), dark mode (easy on the eye), shelf, quick launch shortcuts and many many more.Gestures like drawing > to play next track and < for previous and two finger gesture like double line || to pause playback of music all while screen remains locked and dark. Draw O on locked phone to launch camera, V for flashlight, double-tap screen to wake phone.Thanks to 6 Gigs of RAM, this phone coupled with nova launcher is a treat to use. I totally forgot what lag feels like. Throw any app at it!I can simply wave my hand over the display to see notifications and timeThe fingerprint sensor is very fast which accurately identifies 5 fingerprints in a jiffy.

I get to choose when and what apps want to run secretly in the background trasmiting data or use my device's hardware's only when I permit it to do so. Also it's a non root build in setting on most EUMI builds which makes it easier than other phones. Good luck on your search of what your looking for though as this is a feature that most people are not aware or properly know to use.

1) The fact that it can make and receive calls!! 2)Active Display (or Moto Display), Inside the Moto X Active Display  It is a brilliant feature and works best on AMOLED screens. 3)Touchlesscontrol (or Moto Voice), most phones have some sort of voice control but the screen has to be ON for it to work but here i can start firing my questions even when the phone is in sleep mode Touchless Control and Active Notifications

I have a mi 6 pro  The feature which I like the most is second space. Mi has given this feature in almost all of their products which were launched in last 2–3 years. It is like using 2 phones. feature allows multiple users to access and use the same Android device. The app data and files aren’t shared between them and thus lets each user enjoy a separate space. You can switch simply by using two password or shortcut method. It is one of the best feature provided by redmi. : )
